item.title: A Whiff of Intrigue as Vatican Disputes ‘Unfounded’ Report on Pope Francis’ Health
item.description: A report published by an Italian newspaper that said the pope had a treatable brain tumor fueled suspicion about Francis’ health, which the Vatican denied.
item.dc:creator: LAURIE GOODSTEIN and GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: A Fictional Candidate Draws Attention, and Criticism, in Argentina
item.description: A black candidate invented by advertisers to satirize Sunday’s general election has become an online sensation but also been accused of reviving offensive stereotypes.
item.dc:creator: FREDERICK BERNAS and DIANE GHOGOMU

item.title: Matter: In Ancient DNA, Evidence of Plague Much Earlier Than Previously Known
item.description: A new study suggests that Yersinia pestis, which causes plague, infected people as long as 5,000 years ago.
item.dc:creator: CARL ZIMMER
item.media:description: A human skull from the Yamnaya, a nomadic Bronze Age people from western Russia. Scientists theorize that plague epidemics may have enabled the Yamanaya and other groups of people to move into new territories.

item.title: 13 in Custody in Germany in Possible Plot to Attack Refugees
item.description: Word of the detentions came as German authorities warned against a rise in attacks on shelters for some of the thousands of refugees who have been entering the country.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Albanian migrants in front of an asylum center in Bamberg, Germany. The country has warned of an increase in attacks on shelters.

item.title: U.S. Soldier Is Killed in Raid to Free Prisoners of ISIS in Iraq
item.description: The slain soldier was the first American killed in action in Iraq since the withdrawal in 2011.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe Is Awarded the Confucius Peace Prize
item.description: As prime minister of Zimbabwe, Mr. Mugabe set up an authoritarian system, including managing security forces that on occasion acted as death squads.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, center, at the African Union headquarters in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, in January.

item.title: U.N. Accuses Czech Republic of Violating Migrants’ Rights
item.description: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, the high commissioner for human rights, said “the violations of the human rights of migrants are neither isolated nor coincidental, but systematic.”
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN
item.media:description: A migrant drew a heart on a window in a detention center in Bela-Jezova, Czech Republic, in October. Some are being held for as long as 60 days, the United Nations said, and are being charged $10 each per day for the cost of their detention.

item.title: New Species of Galápagos Tortoise Is Identified
item.description: About 250 members of the species live on the island of Santa Cruz, and genetic evidence indicates that the species has occasionally mated with the other species there.
item.dc:creator: PAM BELLUCK
item.media:description: A new species of tortoise was identified on Santa Cruz, in the center of the Galápagos Islands.

item.title: Hong Kong Journal: Hong Kong’s Drive for ‘Green Burials’ Clashes With Tradition
item.description: Concerned by a scarcity of burial space and a rise in deaths, Hong Kong officials urge the public to scatter ashes in designated gardens or at sea.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives going to Wo Hop Shek to sweep the tomb of a deceased family member in northern Hong Kong.

item.title: Xi’s Visit to Britain Highlights Broader Shift in Concerns About China
item.description: The visit underscores how European nations are de-emphasizing unease about human rights and security as they compete to benefit from China’s growing economic might.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain welcoming President Xi Jinping of China to 10 Downing Street in London on Wednesday.

item.title: Man Kills 2 at School in Sweden and Wounds Several Others
item.description: The suspect, who was armed with a sword or large knife, struck a working-class neighborhood in the city of Trollhattan. He was fatally shot by police.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: Bjorn Larsson Rosvall/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Swedish police officer speaking to a woman outside a school in Trollhattan, Sweden, after an attack on Thursday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Justin Trudeau: Low Expectations, High Relief
item.description: Canadians simply ask that Trudeau, a centrist, not be like his predecessor. We are already pleased!
item.dc:creator: HEATHER MALLICK

item.title: Kerry, Meeting With Netanyahu, Sounds a Cautious Note of Optimism
item.description: But the secretary of state urged Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to soften the language that American and European officials believe is fueling violence in the country.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG and ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Amos Ben Gershom/Israeli Government Press Office
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry met with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in Berlin on Thursday.

item.title: Jewish Man Stabbed in Israel by Palestinians as Violence Continues
item.description: The attack, in which the victim was moderately wounded, was the latest in a wave of assaults that have claimed the lives of eight Israeli Jews and dozens of Palestinians this month.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israeli police officers cordoned off the site of the attack in Beit Shemesh, Israel, on Thursday.

item.title: At War Blog: The Hard Path From Afghanistan to the Classroom
item.description: A high school dropout enlists in the Army, goes to war and realizes that what he really wants in life is a college education.
item.dc:creator: RYAN BLUM
item.media:description: Staff Sgt. Ryan Blum, left, and Specialist Michael Gannon in Kunduz Province, Afghanistan, in 2010.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Camelot Comes to Canada
item.description: The Trudeau story suggests limits to the bullying politics of anger and fear. America, take note.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Attack on Benghazi Mission Brought Chaos Home to City’s Residents
item.description: The battle for the city may now be the most intractable obstacle blocking resolution of the broader conflicts splintering a violence-ridden Libya.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and SULIMAN ALI ZWAY
item.media:description: Gutted buildings in Libya's eastern coastal city of Benghazi on Tuesday.

item.title: Julie Bishop, Foreign Minister of Australia, Raises Eyebrows With Emojis
item.description: Opposition politicians asked whether a red-faced emoji used to describe Russia’s president in an interview had been intended to express displeasure.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Julie Bishop, Australian foreign minister and emoji enthusiast.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Shopping Trip Turns Deadly for Mainland Tourist
item.description: Tensions between residents in Hong Kong and their compatriots in mainland China worsened, as resentment erupted over the death of a mainland tourist in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW and VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: An organized tour group of mainland Chinese assembling for jewelry shopping in the Hung Hom area of Hong Kong.

item.title: Australia’s Migrant Rules Criticized Over Abyan, a Somali Asylum Seeker
item.description: The case of Abyan, a Somali refugee said to have been raped on Nauru, highlights allegations of abuse at island detention centers, rights activists say.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
